sub_title: Professor of Sociology at University of Groningen
summary:
I work on the theoretical and empirical elaboration of a social network approach to bullying. I started to collect data on who bullies with whom to study bullying networks. I also studied the processes underlying bullying and provided evidence that bullies are strategic in selecting victims (Child Development, 2010; Aggressive Behavior, 2013). Recently, I have shown that teachers can play an important role in anti-bullying programs and should be seen as targets of intervention (Journal of Educational Psychology, 2014).

I have applied novel models, methods and software for examining group processes among children and adolescents finding that bullies choose their victims so as to minimize loss of affection by choosing victims who were not likely to be defended by significant others (Child Development, 2007) and that ingroup-outgroup effects are important in explaining the group process of bullying (Aggressive Behavior, 2012). I have advocated longitudinal social network analysis approach in the Handbook of Developmental Research Methods (2012) and as editor of a special issue with seventeen articles on network-behavior dynamics in the Journal of Research on Adolescence (2013). 

In recent years I have coordinated the evaluation of the KiVa anti-bullying program in the Netherlands (see www.kivaschool.nl). KiVa is also a unique source of information for research and analysis, and the first publications from this work have appeared in top 10% journals, showing a higher victimization rate in the classrooms of teachers who attributed bullying to external factors (Journal of Abnormal Child Psychology, 2014) and providing evidence for social support - victims with the same bullies defend each other over time - and retaliation - defenders run the risk of becoming victimized by the bullies of the victims they defend (Development and Psychopathology, 2014).

In 2015 I received a NWO VICI grant for 'Anti-bullying programs 2.0: Tailored interventions to minimize bullying'.

projects.title: KiVa antibullying program
projects.description: KiVa is a research-based antibullying program that has been developed in the University of Turku, Finland, with funding from the Ministry of Education and Culture. The effectiveness of KiVa has been shown in a large randomized controlled trial. In Finland, KiVa is a sought-after program: 90 % of all comprehensive schools in the country are registered KiVa schools implementing the program.

profile_positions.description:
The Royal Holland Society of Sciences and Humanities was established in 1752, in order to promote science (in the broadest sense, including the ‘arts’). It is the oldest learned society in the Netherlands and is constituted as a dual body comprising approximately 380 science promoters (known as directors) and about 480 scholars (known as members), drawn from the natural sciences, the humanities and the social sciences. 

Thanks to its unusual structure, the Society can act as an effective meeting place for leading persons from within and outside academia. It is also in a unique position to provide independent judgement in many fields and does this by serving in the review process for a number of prestigious awards and fellowships. The awards and scholarships are financed by donations from companies, foundations, funds and societies.

Within the Royal Holland Society, exchange of thoughts takes place through lectures and informal interactions.
profile_positions.title: Member of the Royal Holland Society of Sciences and Humanities (KHMW)

profile_positions.description:
The QANU Research Review 2013 evaluated the research program of Sociology, University of Groningen as very good to excellent (4.5 on productivity and viability) and excellent (5.0 on quality and relevance). With 19 out of a maximum of 20 the Groningen program has reached her best result ever. The assessment was carried out by the the QANU (Quality Assurance Netherlands Universities). The evaluation was done by an international committee of leading scholars from Belgium, Germany, the United Kingdom and the United States.

See: http://www.qanu.nl/nl/nieuws/onderzoeksbeoordeling-sociology-afgerond

My former PhD students have found academic positions and are at the forefront on their terrain as evident from the acceptance of their papers in high quality journals, grants for which they successfully applied (VENI, Marie Curie), and prizes they received (ISSBD Young Scientist Award, NSV Dissertation Prize, Praemium Erasmianum).
profile_positions.title: Research Director Department of Sociology

profile_positions.title: Professor of Sociology

company.name: ICS (Interuniversity Center for Social Science Theory and Methodology)

profile_positions.company: ICS (Interuniversity Center for Social Science Theory and Methodology)
profile_positions.description: The Interuniversity Center for Social Science Theory and Methodology (ICS) is a leading research center and graduate school in the social sciences in the Netherlands. It was founded in 1986, and accredited by the Royal Dutch Academy of Arts and Sciences (KNAW) in 1993, 1998, 2003 and most recently in 2012. It is located at four universities: the University of Groningen, Utrecht University, the Radboud University Nijmegen, and the University of Amsterdam.
profile_positions.title: Director

profile_positions.description:
Veenstra, R., Lindenberg, S., Tinga, F., & Ormel, J. (2010). Truancy in late elementary and early secondary education: The influence of social bonds and self-control. International Journal of Behavioral Development, 34, 302-310. 

Veenstra, R., Lindenberg, S., Munniksma, A., & Dijkstra, J.K. (2010). The complex relation between bullying, victimization, acceptance, and rejection: Giving special attention to status, affection, and sex differences. Child Development, 81, 510-516. 

Veenstra, R., Lindenberg, S., Verhulst, F.C., & Ormel, J. (2009). Childhood-limited versus persistent antisocial behavior: Why do some recover and others do not? The TRAILS study. Journal of Early Adolescence, 29, 718-742.
profile_positions.title: Member of Management Team TRAILS

profile_positions.description:
HIGHLIGHT: Special Issue on Network and Behavior Dynamics in Adolescence (published in 2013). The goal of this special issue (17 articles) of Journal of Research on Adolescence was to give an overview of the use of stochastic actor orientated models for analyzing the joint interdependent dynamics of networks and behavior in adolescence. These models can be estimated by software called SIENA, Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis. It has proven to be a useful analytic tool for questions about selection (friends change but behavior stays similar) and influence (friends stay similar but behavior changes) effects, with as strengths that it models unobserved changes between observation points, controls for network structure effects, and takes dependencies in the data into account. 
See:
- Veenstra, R., & Dijkstra, J. K. (2011). Transformations in adolescent peer networks. In B. Laursen & W. A. Collins (Eds.), Relationship pathways: From adolescence to young adulthood (pp. 135-154). Los Angeles: Sage. 
- Veenstra, R. & Steglich, C. (2012). Actor-based model for network and behavior dynamics. In B. Laursen, T.D. Little, & N.A. Card (eds.), Handbook of Developmental Research Methods (pp. 598-618). New York: Guilford.
- Veenstra, R., Dijkstra, J.K., Steglich, C., & Van Zalk, M.H.W. (2013). Network-behavior dynamics. Journal of Research on Adolescence, 23, 399-412.
profile_positions.title: Associate Editor

profile_positions.description: In Finland I worked on the KiVa project for developing an anti-bullying intervention program for the Finnish comprehensive schools. The KiVa project was funded by the Finnish Ministry of Education. It was co-led by PhD Christina Salmivalli (Department of Psychology), and PhD Elisa Poskiparta (Centre of Learning Research) at the University of Turku.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Professor in Psychology
